column4: the question is this: do you want to move all the stuff out of the folder and into another folder, or do you want to copy them?
from the way I read it, you want to move them
move them. My big question is how to select all the contents.
well, the short answer is mv source/* dest/
and a lot more time if you're moving big files.

but the mv command will handle directories inside and stuff correctly. and it will just move the stuff. Genereally, it just shifts what points to the contents of the folder, rather than actually moving anything on the disk.
if you're moving from one disk to another, use cp, because it will take the same amount of time and is safer
you can rm the old directory after the cp completes correctly.
does that make sense to you?
did you get it sorted out?
let me make sure I have this situation right: You've got stuff in /folder/foo/ , but you want everything in there in /folder/ instead?
exactly
go into the folder the stuff is in right now, like this: cd /folder/foo/
then, move everything in that folder to the folder below like this: mv * ..
the mv is "move", * means "Everything in this folder" and .. means "Into the folder above it."
cp will mean it will copy everything, which means that folder will suddenly use twice the space.
mv will just say "You're in /folder/ now, not /folder/foo/"
much, much faster.
that sounds perfect.
be careful when using stuff like .. and ., especially with * and mv or rm. The unix command line has some... oddities.
ntoed.

oh, also be wary of any directories with filenames starting with weird symbols like - or ? or *. - is especially bad. something like rm with a wildcard can find a -r and treat it as a /parameter/ instead of a filename, thus making your delete /recursive/. BAD NEWS! :)
